Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

ALLEGATION:
Agency staff member returned youth to parent on 1/07/22 without a court order. The
youth was later moved from the father's home to a foster home without a removal
order. The foster home's licensed was closed when this occurred.
INVESTIGATION:
Interviews
On 3/17/2022 I received a complaint filed through the on-line complaint allegation
system alleging that Foster Care Worker returned Youth A to the father, Parent A on
01/07/2022 without a court order. In the meantime, the foster family with whom
Youth A had been previously placed, closed their license. Parent A relapsed and
Foster Care Worker removed Youth A from Parent A, without a removal order, and
placed Youth A with Foster Family whose license was voluntarily closed on
01/23/2022. Foster Family’s license reopened on 02/04/2022. The concern is that
the child was returned to the father without an order into an illegal placement. Then
the child was removed from that father again without an order and placed into an
unrelated, unlicensed home without an order.
On 3/24/2022 I interviewed Foster Care Worker, Supervisor, and Program Manager
in person at their agency.
Foster Care Worker reported that at the August and November 2021 court hearings,
discussions were had regarding reunification with Parent A. During the November
court hearing, discussion took place about returning to Parent A once he obtained
2

childcare and family reunification services were established. Foster Care Worker
stated that once these two things were achieved, Youth A was moved from Foster
Parents’ home and placed with Parent A. After Youth A was moved, Foster Parents
voluntarily closed their license. Foster Care Worker stated Parent A had a substance
abuse relapse while Youth A was in his care, so Foster Care Worker contacted the
court regarding issuing a new removal order to which the court responded that no
order was needed since there was no order replacing Youth A with Parent A. Foster
Care Worker stated she didn’t realize until this time that the November court order
stated an Order as Prayed was required prior to returning Youth A to Parent A.
Foster Care Worker reported the court referee told her that the placement with
Parent A would be considered an extended parenting time. Foster Care Worker
reported Youth A was again removed from Parent A and replaced with Foster
Family, who did not have a license to provide care for foster children. Foster Care
Worker reported when she spoke to the court about this placement, they stated that
they would consider the placement to be a “bridge” placement.
Program Manager stated that placing the youth with the unlicensed foster parent
was in the best interest of the child rather than placing him with a licensed family he
did not know, which was why that placement decision was made. Program Manager
and Supervisor reported that this situation was a “learning opportunity” for their
agency as this isn’t anything they have previously encountered.
Documents Reviewed
On 4/4/2022 I reviewed the following in Youth A’s MiSACWIS case record:
 Placement History
- 5/20/2021 – 1/7/2022 Foster Family
- 1/7/2022 - 1/26/2022 Parent A
- 1/26/2022 – Foster Family (unlicensed)
- 2/4/2022 – Foster Family (licensed)
 Court Orders
- Hearing date: 8/17/2021 court ordered Youth A remain in the care and
supervision of the department. Referee signed 8/17/2021, Judge signed
8/19/2021.
- Hearing date: 11/8/2021 court ordered Youth A remain in the care and
supervision of the department. The order also included the following
narrative, “The minor child may be returned to the home of the father on
an Order as Prayed with Intensive Home-Based services and written GAL
approval.” Referee signed 11/8/2021, Judge signed 11/9/2021.
- Hearing date: 3/1/2022 court ordered Youth A remain in the care and
supervision of the department. Referee signed 3/1/2022, Judge signed
3/2/2022.
 Social Work Contacts with Parent A post replacement
3

- 1/13/2022 Foster Care Worker home visit with Parent A & Youth A, worker
reviewed safety plan and conducted FTM with Parent A.
- 1/20/2022 Foster Care Worker home visit with Parent A & Youth A, Parent
admitted to violating safety plan by having Youth A’s mother at the home.
- 2/2/2022 Phone call between Parent A and Foster Care Worker, Parent A
admitted drug relapse.
While reviewing social work contacts, it was noted that a conference had been held
regarding an allegation received by DHHS. I reviewed the allegation dated
1/21/2022 which stated Parent A may be using methamphetamines while Youth A is
in his care and also allowing Youth A’s mother, who is not to have any contact with
Youth A, into Parent A’s home regularly.
Additionally, it was noted that the discussions Foster Care Worker reported having
with the court about the placement were not documented in MiSACWIS.
On 4/4/2022 I reviewed the Foster Family’s case record in MiSACWIS which
documented the following:
- License closed voluntarily on 1/23/2022
- License re-opened 2/4/2022
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12404 Placement.
(1) An agency shall only place a child with an adult who
is legally related to the child, is a legal custodian, or
in a licensed foster home, except as permitted in R
400.12709.
ANALYSIS: Foster Care Worker placed Youth A in the home of Parent A
despite not having legal authority to make the placement. Youth
A was placed in Parent A’s home for 19 days during which
Parent A admitted to violating an established safety plan and
drug use. Foster Care Worker removed Youth A from Parent A
and placed Youth A with an unlicensed foster family. Youth A
remained in an unlicensed placement for 9 days until the foster
home was relicensed.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
